pathogens.name: Neisseria meningitidis
pathogens.definition: Gram-negative diplococcus causing meningococcal meningitis and septicemia (meningococcemia). N. meningitidis is a leading cause of bacterial meningitis worldwide, with potential for rapid progression and high mortality.

primary: Human nasopharynx (asymptomatic carriage in 5-10% of population)
reservoir.notes: Humans are the only reservoir. Asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriage is common, especially in adolescents and young adults. Only certain strains (serogroups A, B, C, W, X, Y) cause invasive disease.

routes: Respiratory droplets from close contact (coughing, sneezing, kissing)
Close living quarters (dormitories, military barracks, households)
transmission.notes: Requires close contact (within 1 meter for >8 hours). Transmission is more common in crowded settings.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Contagious during nasopharyngeal carriage or illness (until 24 hours after effective antibiotic treatment)
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Winter and spring peaks in temperate climates; dry season in sub-Saharan Africa (meningitis belt)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with highest incidence in sub-Saharan Africa (meningitis belt) and among adolescents/young adults

riskFactors: Crowding and close contact (dormitories, military barracks, pilgrimage)
Close contacts of cases (household members, kissing contacts)

symptoms: Petechial or purpuric rash (non-blanching) - hallmark of meningococcemia
complications: Death (10-15% mortality even with treatment; up to 40% without treatment)

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with sudden onset of fever + headache + stiff neck + altered mental status, OR petechial/purpuric rash + epidemiological link to confirmed case
caseDefinition.confirmed: Clinical illness + laboratory confirmation: positive CSF or blood culture for N. meningitidis, OR positive PCR, OR Gram stain showing Gram-negative diplococci in CSF

diagnosis: CSF analysis: elevated WBC (neutrophils), low glucose, high protein
CSF culture (gold standard) - chocolate agar with CO2
Blood culture
PCR for N. meningitidis DNA (CSF, blood)
Gram stain of CSF (Gram-negative diplococci)
Latex agglutination or antigen detection
pathogens.treatment: IV penicillin G or ampicillin (if susceptible), OR third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, cefotaxime - first-line empiric). Supportive care: IV fluids, vasopressors for shock, seizure management. Dexamethasone (adjunct, controversial). Duration: 5-7 days.

infectionControl.precautions: Droplet Precautions (surgical mask, private room if possible) until 24 hours after effective antibiotic treatment
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; identify close contacts for prophylaxis
infectionControl.cohorting: Isolate cases; cohort if multiple cases
infectionControl.sourceControl: Chemoprophylaxis for close contacts (ciprofloxacin, rifampin, or ceftriaxone) within 24 hours
infectionControl.environmental: Standard cleaning; no special environmental measures needed
infectionControl.staffEducation: Droplet precautions, recognition of meningococcal disease (petechial rash, rapid progression), contact identification, chemoprophylaxis protocols

outbreakTriggers: ≥2 confirmed cases epidemiologically linked within 3 months in a community or institution
≥3 cases of same serogroup in population <100,000 over 3 months (attack rate >10 per 100,000)
Single case in closed setting (school, dormitory, military barracks) may trigger enhanced surveillance
reportingCommunication: Immediate notification to public health authorities (within 24 hours or sooner)
Initiate contact tracing and chemoprophylaxis immediately
Vaccination campaigns for at-risk populations (serogroup-specific vaccines)
Public health alerts and media communication
Coordinate with schools, universities, military, or other institutions
Follow national/international outbreak response protocols
prevention: Vaccination for at-risk groups: adolescents, college students, military recruits, pilgrims, travelers to endemic areas
Meningococcal vaccines: MenACWY (conjugate), MenB (recombinant)
Awareness of symptoms and rapid healthcare seeking
Chemoprophylaxis for close contacts
Avoid sharing drinks, utensils, or cigarettes
Respiratory hygiene and cough etiquette
Reduce crowding when possible

pathogens.name: Streptococcus pneumoniae (meningitis)
pathogens.definition: Gram-positive diplococcus causing pneumococcal meningitis, particularly in children and elderly. S. pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults and a leading cause in children, often following respiratory infection or otitis media.

primary: Human nasopharynx (asymptomatic carriage in 5-10% of adults, 20-40% of children)
reservoir.notes: Humans are the only reservoir. Nasopharyngeal carriage is common, especially in young children. Carriage rates vary by age, season, and vaccination status.

routes: Respiratory droplets from close contact (coughing, sneezing)
Autoinoculation from nasopharynx to middle ear or sinuses, then to meninges
transmission.notes: Meningitis often follows respiratory infection, otitis media, or sinusitis. Transmission is person-to-person via respiratory droplets.

incubationPeriod.range: 1-3 days (variable, often follows upper respiratory infection)
incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Contagious during nasopharyngeal carriage or illness
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with higher incidence in developing countries and among unvaccinated populations

riskFactors: Age extremes (young children <2 years, elderly >65 years)
Chronic diseases (diabetes, heart disease, lung disease, liver disease, kidney disease)

symptoms: Altered mental status, confusion, or lethargy
complications: Hearing loss and deafness (30% of survivors)
Neurological sequelae (cognitive impairment, seizures, focal deficits)
Death (15-20% mortality in adults; higher in elderly)

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with fever + headache + stiff neck + altered mental status, often with history of recent respiratory infection, otitis media, or sinusitis
caseDefinition.confirmed: Clinical illness + laboratory confirmation: positive CSF or blood culture for S. pneumoniae, OR positive PCR, OR Gram stain showing Gram-positive diplococci in CSF

diagnosis: CSF analysis: elevated WBC (neutrophils), low glucose, high protein
CSF culture (gold standard) - blood agar
Blood culture
Gram stain of CSF (Gram-positive diplococci, lancet-shaped)
Pneumococcal antigen detection (urine, CSF)
PCR for S. pneumoniae
CT or MRI brain (to assess complications)
pathogens.treatment: High-dose IV penicillin G or ampicillin (if susceptible), OR third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, cefotaxime) + vancomycin (empiric for penicillin-resistant strains). Dexamethasone (adjunct, given before or with first antibiotic dose - reduces mortality and hearing loss). Duration: 10-14 days.

infectionControl.precautions: Droplet Precautions (surgical mask) for first 24 hours of effective antibiotic treatment; then Standard Precautions
infectionControl.cohorting: Isolate cases during first 24 hours of treatment
infectionControl.staffEducation: Droplet precautions, recognition of meningitis symptoms, vaccination importance, dexamethasone administration timing

outbreakTriggers: Single confirmed case in closed setting (daycare, nursing home, school)
reportingCommunication: Prompt notification to public health authorities (within 24 hours)
Initiate contact investigation in closed settings
Assess vaccination coverage in affected population
Consider vaccination campaigns if outbreak involves vaccine-preventable serotypes
Update stakeholders and healthcare providers
prevention: Vaccination: PCV13 (pneumococcal conjugate vaccine) for children and high-risk adults; PPSV23 (pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine) for adults ≥65 years and high-risk groups
Awareness of symptoms and rapid healthcare seeking
Respiratory hygiene and cough etiquette
Smoking cessation
Management of chronic diseases
Prompt treatment of respiratory infections, otitis media, and sinusitis

pathogens.name: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
pathogens.definition: Gram-negative coccobacillus; major cause of childhood meningitis before Hib vaccine. H. influenzae type b was the leading cause of bacterial meningitis in children <5 years before widespread vaccination.

primary: Human nasopharynx (asymptomatic carriage in 2-5% of children, <1% of adults)
reservoir.notes: Humans are the only reservoir. Carriage rates have dramatically decreased since introduction of Hib vaccine. Non-typeable H. influenzae (NTHi) can also cause invasive disease but is less common.

routes: Respiratory droplets from close contact (coughing, sneezing)
Close contact with carriers or cases (household, daycare)
transmission.notes: Transmission requires close contact. Invasive disease is rare in vaccinated populations.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Contagious during nasopharyngeal carriage or illness (until 24-48 hours after effective antibiotic treatment)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with highest incidence in unvaccinated populations and developing countries

riskFactors: Close contacts of cases (household members, daycare)

symptoms: Stiff neck (nuchal rigidity) - may be absent in infants
complications: Hearing loss and deafness (15-30% of survivors)
Neurological sequelae (developmental delay, cognitive impairment, seizures)
Death (3-6% mortality with treatment; higher without treatment)
Other invasive Hib diseases (epiglottitis, pneumonia, septic arthritis)

caseDefinition.suspected: Child with fever + irritability + stiff neck + lethargy, OR bulging fontanelle (infants) + history of incomplete Hib vaccination or exposure to case
caseDefinition.confirmed: Clinical illness + laboratory confirmation: positive CSF or blood culture for H. influenzae type b, OR positive PCR with serotyping confirming type b

diagnosis: CSF analysis: elevated WBC (neutrophils), low glucose, high protein
CSF culture (gold standard) - chocolate agar with CO2
Blood culture
Gram stain of CSF (Gram-negative coccobacilli)
PCR for H. influenzae
Serotyping to confirm type b (capsular antigen detection)
Latex agglutination for capsular antigen
pathogens.treatment: Third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime) - first-line empiric (due to ampicillin resistance). Dexamethasone (adjunct, given before or with first antibiotic dose - reduces hearing loss). Duration: 7-10 days.

infectionControl.precautions: Droplet Precautions (surgical mask) until 24 hours after effective antibiotic treatment
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; identify close contacts for prophylaxis
infectionControl.cohorting: Isolate cases during first 24 hours of treatment
infectionControl.sourceControl: Chemoprophylaxis for close contacts (rifampin) if household includes unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated children <4 years
infectionControl.staffEducation: Droplet precautions, recognition of invasive Hib disease, vaccination importance, contact prophylaxis protocols

outbreakTriggers: Any confirmed invasive Hib case triggers outbreak investigation (especially in vaccinated populations)
≥2 cases in same community or institution within 60 days
Single case in daycare or household with unvaccinated children
Cluster suggesting vaccine failure or waning immunity
reportingCommunication: Urgent notification to public health authorities (within 24 hours)
Implement outbreak control measures immediately
Chemoprophylaxis for household and daycare contacts
Assess vaccination coverage and vaccine failure
Public health alerts and vaccination campaigns if needed
Coordinate with pediatric and infectious disease specialists
prevention: Hib vaccination: primary series at 2, 4, 6 months + booster at 12-15 months (part of routine childhood immunization)
Catch-up vaccination for unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated children
Chemoprophylaxis for close contacts (rifampin)
Respiratory hygiene and cough etiquette
Awareness of symptoms and rapid healthcare seeking
Breastfeeding (protective effect)
Avoid exposure to tobacco smoke

pathogens.name: Listeria monocytogenes (meningitis)
pathogens.definition: Gram-positive rod causing neurolisteriosis (meningitis, meningoencephalitis) particularly in neonates, elderly, and immunocompromised. Listeria is a foodborne pathogen with tropism for the central nervous system in vulnerable populations.

primary: Contaminated food (ready-to-eat foods, unpasteurized dairy, deli meats)
reservoir.notes: Listeria is ubiquitous in the environment and can grow at refrigeration temperatures (4°C). Foodborne transmission is the primary route for meningitis.

routes: Ingestion of contaminated food (ready-to-eat foods, deli meats, soft cheeses, unpasteurized dairy)
Vertical transmission (mother to fetus during pregnancy - neonatal meningitis)
Rarely: direct contact with infected animals or contaminated materials
transmission.notes: Meningitis occurs after foodborne ingestion with bacteremia and CNS invasion. Neonatal meningitis can occur via vertical transmission or early postnatal exposure.

incubationPeriod.range: Days to weeks (typically 1-4 weeks for invasive disease; can be up to 70 days)
incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Not person-to-person contagious (except vertical transmission during pregnancy)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with higher incidence in developed countries due to consumption of ready-to-eat foods

riskFactors: Pregnancy (risk of vertical transmission to fetus/neonate)
Chronic diseases (diabetes, liver disease, kidney disease)
Consumption of high-risk foods (deli meats, soft cheeses, unpasteurized dairy)

symptoms: Altered mental status, confusion, or lethargy
Neonates: irritability, poor feeding, lethargy, respiratory distress
complications: Neurological sequelae (cognitive impairment, seizures, focal deficits)

caseDefinition.suspected: High-risk patient (immunocompromised, elderly, neonate, pregnant) with fever + meningitis/encephalitis symptoms + compatible food exposure history
caseDefinition.confirmed: Clinical illness + laboratory confirmation: positive CSF or blood culture for L. monocytogenes, OR positive PCR from CSF

diagnosis: CSF analysis: elevated WBC (lymphocytes or neutrophils), low glucose, high protein
CSF culture (gold standard) - may take 48-72 hours
Blood culture
Gram stain of CSF (Gram-positive rods, may be sparse)
PCR for Listeria species
MRI brain (may show rhombencephalitis - brainstem lesions)
Serotyping and molecular subtyping (PFGE, WGS) for outbreak investigation
pathogens.treatment: Ampicillin or penicillin G + gentamicin (synergistic combination) for 3-6 weeks (longer than other bacterial meningitis). Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for penicillin-allergic patients. Supportive care: seizure management, ICP monitoring. Dexamethasone NOT recommended (may reduce ampicillin penetration into CSF).

infectionControl.precautions: Standard Precautions (not person-to-person contagious, except vertical transmission)
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; test high-risk patients with compatible illness
infectionControl.sourceControl: Identify and eliminate contaminated food sources; product recall if outbreak
infectionControl.environmental: Safe food handling and storage; environmental monitoring in food processing facilities
infectionControl.staffEducation: Food safety education for high-risk populations, recognition of neurolisteriosis (rhombencephalitis), prolonged treatment duration

outbreakTriggers: Even a single invasive case (including meningitis) demands public health action
≥2 cases with same molecular subtype (PFGE, WGS)
Cluster of cases with common food exposure
Detection of Listeria in food products or processing environment
reportingCommunication: Rapid notification to public health authorities (within 24 hours)
Engage food safety authorities immediately
Coordinate product recall if contaminated food identified
Molecular subtyping (PFGE, WGS) to link cases
Trace-back investigation to identify contaminated products
Public health alerts to high-risk populations
prevention: Food hygiene and safety education for vulnerable populations (avoid deli meats, soft cheeses, unpasteurized dairy unless heated)
Proper food handling and storage (refrigeration <4°C slows but does not stop growth)
Pasteurization of milk and dairy products
Reheat ready-to-eat foods to steaming hot (165°F/74°C) before consumption
Environmental monitoring in food processing facilities
Pregnant women should avoid high-risk foods
Cold chain monitoring
